I had been so caught up in my research, collecting samples and data from the glacier, that I had almost forgotten about the warning, until Dr. Merel's urgent call snapped me back to reality. Now, as I huddle in my tent, listening to the howling wind and the creaking of the glacier, I can feel the weight of my isolation. The satphone crackles to life again, and I hear Dr. Merel's voice, "Can you hear me? We're trying to get a team to you as soon as possible, but it's not looking good. Just stay safe and stay put." I nod, even though I know he can't see me, and reply, "Roger that, I'll be here." The line goes dead, and I'm left with only my thoughts, and the sound of the storm raging on outside.

As we continue to explore Mars and push the boundaries of what is possible, we must learn from the experiences of Spirit and Opportunity and strive to create even more resilient and capable spacecraft that can withstand the unforgiving environment of the Red Planet.
